citations.narrative:
The individual microchip numbers are not listed on acquisition forms for dogs and cats. Maintaining records of the official
USDA tag number or tattoo assigned to each dog or cat acquired for and used in research assists APHIS Officials in
carrying out their duties of determining compliance and good animal welfare. All official tag or tattoo numbers shall be
correctly listed in the records of purchase, acquisition, disposal, or sale of all live dogs or cats which shall be maintained
in accordance with 2.35.
Correct from this date forward of 21 November 2025.

The microchip number is not recorded on medical records for dogs. Official identification documented on medical records
is necessary for APHIS officials to determine which dog/puppy the record belongs to and if the animal has received
adequate veterinary care. Each research facility shall keep copies of medical records that include the identity of the
animal including identifying marks, tattoos, or tags and the animal's breed, sex and age. The research facility must ensure
that all medical records contain the identification of the animal as well as all other required information.
Correct from this date forward of 21 November 2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.38(g)(2) 
   
Miscellaneous. 
The individual microchip numbers are not listed on acquisition forms for dogs and cats. Maintaining records of the official 
USDA tag number or tattoo assigned to each dog or cat acquired for and used in research assists APHIS Officials in 
carrying out their duties of determining compliance and good animal welfare. All official tag or tattoo numbers shall be 
correctly listed in the records of purchase, acquisition, disposal, or sale of all live dogs or cats which shall be maintained 
in accordance with 2.35.  
 
Correct from this date forward of 21 November 2025. 
3.13(b)(1) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The microchip number is not recorded on medical records for dogs. Official identification documented on medical records 
is necessary for APHIS officials to determine which dog/puppy the record belongs to and if the animal has received 
adequate veterinary care. Each research facility shall keep copies of medical records that include the identity of the 
animal including identifying marks, tattoos, or tags and the animal's breed, sex and age. The research facility must ensure 
that all medical records contain the identification of the animal as well as all other required information. 
 
Correct from this date forward of 21 November 2025. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
